moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Nf3 Nf6 4. e3 g6 5. Bxc4 Bg7 6. O-O O-O 7. Nc3 Nfd7
1. d4 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Nf3 Nf6 4. e3 g6 5. Bxc4 Bg7 6. O-O O-O 7. Nc3 Nfd7 8. Qe2 Nb6 9. Bb3 Nc6
comment: !? An attempt to improve on Golombek - Smyslov, Budapest 1952, which saw 9...a5.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Nf3 Nf6 4. e3 g6 5. Bxc4 Bg7 6. O-O O-O 7. Nc3 Nfd7 8. Qe2 Nb6 9. Bb3 Nc6 10. Rd1 Bg4 11. h3 Bxf3 12. Qxf3 Qe8
comment: This move has the goal of blasting open the center. After the king moves to the h-file Black can advance both e- and f-pawns.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Nf3 Nf6 4. e3 g6 5. Bxc4 Bg7 6. O-O O-O 7. Nc3 Nfd7 8. Qe2 Nb6 9. Bb3 Nc6 10. Rd1 Bg4 11. h3 Bxf3 12. Qxf3 Qe8 13. Nb5
comment:
?! 
Gligoric improved against me a week or two later with 13. Ne4!, with the threat
of Nc5. Serves me right for getting the game published in the New York Times!

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Nf3 Nf6 4. e3 g6 5. Bxc4 Bg7 6. O-O O-O 7. Nc3 Nfd7 8. Qe2 Nb6 9. Bb3 Nc6 10. Rd1 Bg4 11. h3 Bxf3 12. Qxf3 Qe8 13. Nb5 Rc8 14. Bd2 a6 15. Na3 Kh8 16. Rac1 e5 17. d5 e4 18. Qf4
comment:
It is clear that the Nc6 is headed for e5, with the possibility of jumping into
f3. If only the g-file were open and a rook stood on g8...

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Nf3 Nf6 4. e3 g6 5. Bxc4 Bg7 6. O-O O-O 7. Nc3 Nfd7 8. Qe2 Nb6 9. Bb3 Nc6 10. Rd1 Bg4 11. h3 Bxf3 12. Qxf3 Qe8 13. Nb5 Rc8 14. Bd2 a6 15. Na3 Kh8 16. Rac1 e5 17. d5 e4 18. Qf4 g5 19. Qxg5 Ne5 20. Bc3
comment: The pin looks strong - but checks have been known to break pins!

comment: Black continues to make threats while improving the position of his queen, before capturing the pawn at b2.

comment: Reshevsky finally resigned, since I'm going to sac the rook for the knight and grab the e-pawn, with a three pawn advantage.
